frameDefinitions: Two or more distinct entities, which may be concrete or abstract objects or types, are characterized as being similar to each other.

A Theme changes location with respect to a salient location, which can be expressed by a Source, Path, Goal, Area, Direction, Path_shape, or Distance, as shown in the examples below: ''  'Start your ascent from Achintree Farm in Glen Nevis.'
This Frame is concerned with evaluating an Evaluee as being suitable for a Purpose or a User, presupposing some choice that is being made about which Evaluee to use for the Purpose or User.
In this frame a Patient is in a phase brought about after a change of phase.
The existence of a State_of_affairs is sufficient reason for taking an Action .
The Protagonist is in an initial state, before beginning to be involved in the Activity, but all pre-conditions for performance of the Activity have been satisfied.
frameExamples:
A mulberry is very <t>similar</t> in shape
to a loganberry
Start your <t>ascent</t> from Achintree Farm in Glen Nevis.
(1) We need to build more houses <t>suitable</t> for local residents.
Collect up the  <t>thawed</t> water from the freezer section.
The underwater sequences <t>warrant</t> the price of the admission alone.
listRoleDefinitions: This role marks constituents that express the set of objects or types whose similarity is at issue.

When there is an asymmetry, <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the entity characterized by its similarity to <fen>Entity_2</fen>, whose characteristics are assumed to be known.  <fen>Entity_1</fen> is often an external argument.

When the <fen>Entities</fen> are expressed separately, <fen>Entity_2</fen> is the one whose characteristics are assumed to be known; it serves as a basis for establishing characteristics of <fen>Entity_1</fen>.
This role marks constituents which express a property in respect to which the similarity of the entities is assessed.
A fact about <fen>Entity_1</fen> or the <fen>Entities</fen> that reveals how <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the same or different from other entities.  (Note the contrast with 'as to'.)
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the similarity occurs or exists.
The Place is the general area in which similarity occurs or exists

This is the object which moves. In many sentences this role will be expressed as something which moves under its own power. However, this role is not <ment>required</ment> to be an animate mover, so it is different from Self_mover.

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. In particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
Any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen> (see below) expresses the frame element <fen>Path</fen>, including directional expressions:
Any expression which tells where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element Goal.
Any expression which characterizes the extent of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Distance</fen>.
This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.
The configuration formed by the entire <fen>Path</fen> of the <fen>Theme</fen>, taken simultaneously.
The direction in which the <fen>Theme</fen> goes.
The time at which the motion takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.
This Frame Element marks constituents expressing the entity that is judged to be more or less suitable for some <fen>Purpose</fen> or <fen>User</fen>.
This Frame Element marks constituents that express the <fen>Purpose</fen> for which the <fen>Evaluee</fen> is judged to be suitable or unsuitable.
This role marks expressions that indicate a <fen>User</fen> to whom
The <fen>Substance</fen> is the entity which has had its phase altered.
An Eventuality or an Entity that is taken to constitute sufficient reason for taking another <fen>Action</fen>.
An <fen>Action</fen> that is taken to be justifiable given the <fen>State_of_Affairs</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Protagonist</fen> in the initial state of an activity.
The action that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is prepared to do.
An entity which stands in metonymically for the <fen>Activity</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is ready.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The two painters</fex> were alike in being unable to draw acceptably .
In the first phase <fex>Barthes's approach</fex> has similarities to that of Levi-Strauss.
The results of Method 2 show remarkable similarity <fex>to those obtained by Method 1</fex>
The disc announced Friday is <fex>physically</fex> similar to current music CDs
His presidency was different <fex>in that it offered a way forward for the common man</fex> .
<fex>Kim</fex> crossed through the woods.
The cat crossed the street <fex>from her yard</fex>.
The bikers crisscrossed <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children hopped <fex>into the neighbor's yard</fex>.
I leaped <fex>twenty feet</fex> before slipping and falling.
The bikers crisscrossed <fex>the desert</fex>.
He circled downward <fex>in a spiral</fex>.
The frogs jumped <fex>down</fex> through the meadow.
They crisscrossed the country <fex>in April</fex>.
Being a project leader is not a job for which <fex>everybody</fex> is suited.
We need to plan more buildings suitable <fex>for disabled people</fex>.
<fex>A heavy contact to the opponent 's face</fex> may not merit just a verbal warning
The end justifies <fex>the means</fex>.
The students were finally ready <fex>to take the exam</fex> .
Are you ready <fex>for a baby</fex> ?
He looks like he 's ready <fex>now</fex> .
